item.title: - Spin-Orbit Interaction in Hydrogen-like Atoms
item.description: Total Angular Momentum and Commutation Relations # For a single electron with orbital angular momentum $\mathbf{L}$ and spin $\mathbf{S}$, we define the total angular momentum as $$\mathbf{J} = \mathbf{L} + \mathbf{S}.$$ The square of $\mathbf{J}$ is given by $$J^2 = L^2 + S^2 + 2\ \mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{S}.$$ Hence, $$\mathbf{L} \cdot \mathbf{S} \ =\ \frac{1}{2}\Bigl(J^2 - L^2 - S^2\Bigr).$$ Because $$[J_z,\ L^2] = [J_z,\ S^2] = [J_z,\ J^2] = 0,$$
